CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 6 To improve the PCE , the following idealistic conditions are required in conjugated polymers : 14 ( 1 ) a low bandgap with a wide absorption area , ( 2 ) a crystalline structure to produce good charge transport characteristics , ( 3 ) a low highest occupied molecular orbital ( HOMO ) energy level to produce a high open - circuit voltage ( V oc ) , and ( 4 ) an appropriate lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) energy level for effective electron charge transfer to fullerene.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Here are the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| conjugated polymers |
| low bandgap |
| wide absorption area |
| crystalline structure |
| charge transport characteristics |
| HOMO energy level |
| V oc |
| LUMO energy level |
| fullerene |

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Of course! Here are the valid "Material Name" entities in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| conjugated polymers |
| fullerene |

I removed the following entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name":

* "low bandgap" and "wide absorption area" are not material names, but rather properties of materials.
* "charge transport characteristics" is a general term that refers to the ability of a material to transport charges, but it is not a specific material name.
* "HOMO energy level" and "LUMO energy level" are not material names, but rather terms used in the context of molecular orbitals.
